我可以联网帮你查最新数据，不过刚才直接打开部分权威页面（搜索引擎结果、浙江大学本科招生网、阳光高考等）时遇到反爬或连接限制，没能直接获取到具体分数与位次。

为避免误差，先确认两点：
1) 你想查的是本科高考录取，还是研究生（推免/统考）？
2) 若是本科，请提供：省份、选科要求（物理等）、想看的口径（投档线/位次/最高-最低-平均分/招生计划数）。我就能定向抓取对应省考试院或浙大本科招生网的页面给你精确数据。

同时给你几条权威查询路径（你也可把页面链接发我，我来代查）：
- 浙江大学本科招生网（各省投档线/分数线/计划）：bkzs.zju.edu.cn（有时需从首页导航“录取查询/各省分数线”进入）
- 各省教育考试院官网（“本科批投档线/录取统计”栏目）
- 阳光高考平台（高校分数线-浙江大学页）

背景提示（不代替具体数据）：2024年计算机类在各顶尖高校普遍竞争最激烈，浙大“信息类/计算机类”在多数省份的投档线与位次基本处在全省顶尖区间，常高于同校不少专业。具体到你所在省份和批次差异很大，建议用权威投档线和位次对照。

告诉我你的省份和想看的口径，我立即再试联网抓取并整理成清单发你。

function.arguments: {"query":"SELECT id, source, substr(content,1,200) AS snippet FROM docs ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT 20;"}

Help me find some papers about control system about the topic of  marine ship controlling in the Arxiv and summarize these papers and wtire them into my Notion as a new page.

function.name: search_papers
function.arguments: {"query": "ti:\"ship control\" OR ti:\"marine vessel\" OR ti:\"autonomous surface vessel\"", "max_results": 10}

function.name: search_papers
function.arguments: {"query": "marine vessel control AND (\"dynamic positioning\" OR \"path following\" OR \"course keeping\")", "max_results": 10}

function.name: search_papers
function.arguments: {"query": "(autonomous surface vessel OR ASV) AND (control OR guidance OR navigation) AND (reinforcement learning OR MPC OR backstepping OR sliding mode)", "max_results": 10}

["Title: Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of Autonomous Surface Vessels

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Trym Tengesdal, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-03-27T21:57:18Z
- Last Updated: 2024-03-27T21:57:18Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
This article proposes an approach for collision avoidance, path following, and anti-grounding of autonomous surface vessels under consideration of environmental forces based on Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC). Artificial Potential Fields (APFs) set the foundation for the cost function of the optimal control problem in terms of collision avoidance and anti-grounding. Depending on the risk of a collision given by the resulting force of the APFs, the controller optimizes regarding an adapted heading and travel speed by additionally following a desired path. For this purpose, nonlinear vessel dynamics are used for the NMPC. To extend the situational awareness concerning environmental disturbances impacted by wind, waves, and sea currents, a nonlinear disturbance observer is coupled to the entire NMPC scheme, allowing for the correction of an incorrect vessel motion due to external forces. In addition, the most essential rules according to the Convention on the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) are considered. The results of the simulations show that the proposed framework can control an autonomous surface vessel under various challenging scenarios, including environmental disturbances, to avoid collisions and follow desired paths.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.19028v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2403.19028v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.19028v1
"]

["Title: This is the Way: Mitigating the Roll of an Autonomous Uncrewed Surface Vessel in Wavy Conditions Using Model Predictive Control

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel L. Jenkins, Joshua A. Marshall
- Published: 2024-08-27T18:21:10Z
- Last Updated: 2024-08-27T18:21:10Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: eess.SY

Abstract:
Though larger vessels may be well-equipped to deal with wavy conditions, smaller vessels are often more susceptible to disturbances. This paper explores the development of a nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) system for Uncrewed Surface Vessels (USVs) in wavy conditions to minimize average roll. The NMPC is based on a prediction method that uses information about the vessel's dynamics and an assumed wave model. This method is able to mitigate the roll of an under-actuated USV in a variety of conditions by adjusting the weights of the cost function. The results show a reduction of 39% of average roll with a tuned controller in conditions with 1.75-metre sinusoidal waves. A general and intuitive tuning strategy is established. This preliminary work is a proof of concept which sets the stage for the leveraging of wave prediction methodologies to perform planning and control in real time for USVs in real-world scenarios and field trials.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.15349v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2408.15349v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.15349v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: 6 pages, 10 figures. To appear in Proceedings of the 2024 IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Robots and Systems (IROS), October 2024
"]

["Title: Digital Twin of Autonomous Surface Vessels for Safe Maritime Navigation Enabled through Predictive Modeling and Reinforcement Learning

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Andreas Von Brandis, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-01-08T17:17:08Z
- Last Updated: 2024-03-30T10:18:12Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: eess.SY

Abstract:
Autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) play an increasingly important role in the safety and sustainability of open sea operations. Since most maritime accidents are related to human failure, intelligent algorithms for autonomous collision avoidance and path following can drastically reduce the risk in the maritime sector. A DT is a virtual representative of a real physical system and can enhance the situational awareness (SITAW) of such an ASV to generate optimal decisions. This work builds on an existing DT framework for ASVs and demonstrates foundations for enabling predictive, prescriptive, and autonomous capabilities. In this context, sophisticated target tracking approaches are crucial for estimating and predicting the position and motion of other dynamic objects. The applied tracking method is enabled by real-time automatic identification system (AIS) data and synthetic light detection and ranging (Lidar) measurements. To guarantee safety during autonomous operations, we applied a predictive safety filter, based on the concept of nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC). The approaches are implemented into a DT built with the Unity game engine. As a result, this work demonstrates the potential of a DT capable of making predictions, playing through various what-if scenarios, and providing optimal control decisions according to its enhanced SITAW.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04032v2
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2401.04032v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.04032v2
"]

["Title: Digital Twin for Autonomous Surface Vessels: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-11-05T19:35:23Z
- Last Updated: 2024-11-05T19:35:23Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY, Additional: cs.RO

Abstract:
Autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) are becoming increasingly significant in enhancing the safety and sustainability of maritime operations. To ensure the reliability of modern control algorithms utilized in these vessels, digital twins (DTs) provide a robust framework for conducting safe and effective simulations within a virtual environment. Digital twins are generally classified on a scale from 0 to 5, with each level representing a progression in complexity and functionality: Level 0 (Standalone) employs offline modeling techniques; Level 1 (Descriptive) integrates sensors and online modeling to enhance situational awareness; Level 2 (Diagnostic) focuses on condition monitoring and cybersecurity; Level 3 (Predictive) incorporates predictive analytics; Level 4 (Prescriptive) embeds decision-support systems; and Level 5 (Autonomous) enables advanced functionalities such as collision avoidance and path following. These digital representations not only provide insights into the vessel's current state and operational efficiency but also predict future scenarios and assess life endurance. By continuously updating with real-time sensor data, the digital twin effectively corrects modeling errors and enhances decision-making processes. Since DTs are key enablers for complex autonomous systems, this paper introduces a comprehensive methodology for establishing a digital twin framework specifically tailored for ASVs. Through a detailed literature survey, we explore existing state-of-the-art enablers across the defined levels, offering valuable recommendations for future research and development in this rapidly evolving field.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.03465v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2411.03465v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.03465v1
"]

["Title: Practical identification approach for the actuation dynamics of autonomous surface vehicles with minimal instrumentation: extended version

Metadata:
- Authors: Thalia Morel, Luis Orihuela, Christophe Combastel, Guillermo Bejarano
- Published: 2024-10-01T12:27:47Z
- Last Updated: 2024-10-10T07:17:41Z
- Categories: Primary: math.DS, Additional: eess.SY
- DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2024.120098

Abstract:
A practical method for identifying the propeller model and inertia matrix of a marine Autonomous Surface Vehicle (ASV) is proposed in this work. Special attention is paid to limiting the instrumentation requirements. Based on a generic grey-box dynamic modelling addressing the considered catamaran-shaped ASV architecture, the static/dynamic behaviour of both propellers and the vessel dynamic are jointly estimated using the sole measurements of position, heading, and propellers pulse width modulation (PWM) signals. No accelerometer is required. Two distinct grey-box configurations involving either a static polynomial or a dynamic modelling of each propeller are proposed and compared. The resulting ASV identification methodology is shown to provide insight into the whole vessel inertial characteristics, which are key enablers in the development of autonomous navigation and control systems. Model validation was performed using data collected from the reported experiments. Model prediction errors related to both linear velocities and yaw rate are evaluated and compared based on given metrics. The results underscore the robustness and accuracy of the identified models in capturing the essential dynamics of the ASV, with a determination coefficient that consistently exceeds 0.94 for all estimated velocities.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2024.120098
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2410.00631v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.00631v2
"]

["Title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Tracking Control of an Autonomous Surface Vessel in Natural Waters

Metadata:
- Authors: Wei Wang, Xiaojing Cao, Alejandro Gonzalez-Garcia, Lianhao Yin, Niklas Hagemann, Yuanyuan Qiao, Carlo Ratti, Daniela Rus
- Published: 2023-02-16T05:50:07Z
- Last Updated: 2023-02-20T19:26:40Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO

Abstract:
Accurate control of autonomous marine robots still poses challenges due to the complex dynamics of the environment. In this paper, we propose a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) approach to train a controller for autonomous surface vessel (ASV) trajectory tracking and compare its performance with an advanced nonlinear model predictive controller (NMPC) in real environments. Taking into account environmental disturbances (e.g., wind, waves, and currents), noisy measurements, and non-ideal actuators presented in the physical ASV, several effective reward functions for DRL tracking control policies are carefully designed. The control policies were trained in a simulation environment with diverse tracking trajectories and disturbances. The performance of the DRL controller has been verified and compared with the NMPC in both simulations with model-based environmental disturbances and in natural waters. Simulations show that the DRL controller has 53.33% lower tracking error than that of NMPC. Experimental results further show that, compared to NMPC, the DRL controller has 35.51% lower tracking error, indicating that DRL controllers offer better disturbance rejection in river environments than NMPC.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08100v2
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2302.08100v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.08100v2

Additional Information:
- Comment: ICRA 2023
"]

["Title: Collision Avoidance for Autonomous Surface Vessels using Novel Artificial Potential Fields

Metadata:
- Authors: Aditya Kailas Jadhav, Anantha Raj Pandi, Abhilash Somayajula
- Published: 2023-10-09T09:43:36Z
- Last Updated: 2023-10-09T09:43:36Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: cs.CE, eess.SY
- DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2023.116011
- Journal Reference: Ocean Engineering, 288 (2023), 116011

Abstract:
As the demand for transportation through waterways continues to rise, the number of vessels plying the waters has correspondingly increased. This has resulted in a greater number of accidents and collisions between ships, some of which lead to significant loss of life and financial losses. Research has shown that human error is a major factor responsible for such incidents. The maritime industry is constantly exploring newer approaches to autonomy to mitigate this issue. This study presents the use of novel Artificial Potential Fields (APFs) to perform obstacle and collision avoidance in marine environments. This study highlights the advantage of harmonic functions over traditional functions in modeling potential fields. With a modification, the method is extended to effectively avoid dynamic obstacles while adhering to COLREGs. Improved performance is observed as compared to the traditional potential fields and also against the popular velocity obstacle approach. A comprehensive statistical analysis is also performed through Monte Carlo simulations in different congested environments that emulate real traffic conditions to demonstrate robustness of the approach.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2023.116011

Additional Information:
- Comment: 28 pages, 30 figures
"]

["Title: Development of a Hybrid Simulation and Experiment Test Platform for Dynamic Positioning Vessels

Metadata:
- Authors: Changjun Hu, Quan Shi, Xin Li, Xiaoxian Guo
- Published: 2022-10-23T05:32:26Z
- Last Updated: 2022-10-23T05:32:26Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
The harsh ocean environment and complex operating condition require high dynamic positioning (DP) capability of offshore vessel. The design, development and performance evaluation of DP system are generally carried out by numerical simulations or scale model experiments. Compared with the time-consuming and laborious experiment, the simulation is convenient and low cost, but its results lack practical reference due to oversimplification of the model. Therefore, this paper presents a hybrid simulation and experiment test platform for DP vessels. Its characteristics are: the realistic calculation of environmental loads and motion response, the consistency of algorithms and parameters for simulation and experiment greatly shortening the time of experiment adjusting, switchable and online renewable controller facilitating algorithm testing. The test platform can test the performance of DP system and determine the operational time window. In the hydrodynamic simulation, the six degree-of-freedom model is used to describe the dynamic response of the DP vessel, considering the fluid memory effect and frequency-dependent hydrodynamic parameters. In the experiment, the similarity theory based on the same Froude number is used to ensure the consistency of control parameters with simulation. Finally, a case study of DP shuttle tanker is used to verify the credibility of the test platform.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12621v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2210.12621v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.12621v1
"]

["Title: Optimal Trajectory Planning and Model Predictive Control of Underactuated Marine Surface Vessels using a Flatness-Based Approach

Metadata:
- Authors: Max Lutz, Thomas Meurer
- Published: 2021-01-29T18:42:47Z
- Last Updated: 2021-01-29T18:42:47Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY, Additional: math.OC
- DOI: 10.23919/ACC50511.2021.9483265

Abstract:
This paper demonstrates a refined approach to solving dynamic optimization problems for underactuated marine surface vessels. To this end the differential flatness of a mathematical model assuming full actuation is exploited to derive an efficient representation of a finite dimensional nonlinear programming problem, which in turn is constrained to apply to the underactuated case. It is illustrated how the properties of the flat output can be employed for the generation of an initial guess to be used in the optimization algorithm in the presence of static and dynamic obstacles. As an example energy optimal point to point trajectory planning for a nonlinear 3 degrees of freedom dynamic model of an underactuated surface vessel is undertaken. Input constraints, both in rate and magnitude as well as state constraints due to convex and non-convex obstacles in the area of operation are considered and simulation results for a challenging scenario are reported. Furthermore, an extension to a trajectory tracking controller using model predictive control is made where the benefits of the flatness based direct method allow to introduce nonuniform sample times that help to realize long prediction horizons while maintaining short term accuracy and real time capability. This is also verified in simulation where additional disturbances in the form of environmental disturbances, dynamic obstacles and parameter mismatch are introduced.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.23919/ACC50511.2021.9483265
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2101.12730v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.12730v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: Accepted for presentation at, and publication in the proceedings of, the 2021 American Control Conference (ACC)
"]

["Title: Observer Based Path Following for Underactuated Marine Vessels in the Presence of Ocean Currents: A Global Approach - With proofs

Metadata:
- Authors: D. J. W. Belleter, M. Maghenem, C. Paliotta, K. Y. Pettersen
- Published: 2018-10-11T21:03:15Z
- Last Updated: 2018-10-11T21:03:15Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
In this paper a solution to the problem of following a curved path in the presence of a constant unknown ocean current disturbance is presented. We introduce a path variable that represents the curvilinear abscissa on the path which is used to propagate the path-tangential reference frame. The proposed dynamic update law of the path variable is non singular and the guidance law is designed such that the vessel can reject constant unknown ocean currents by using an ocean current observer. It is shown that the closed-loop system composed of the guidance law, controller and observer provides globally asymptotically stable and locally exponentially stable path following errors. The sway velocity dynamics is analyzed and, under adequate hypothesis on the path curvature, it is shown that the dynamics are well behaved and that the guidance law to exist. Simulations are presented to verify the theoretical findings.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.06974v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/1810.06974v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.06974v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:1704.00573
"]

function.name: notion-create-pages
function.arguments:
{"pages":[{"content":"# Marine Ship Control: Selected arXiv Papers (Control Systems)

## Scope
Autonomous surface vessel (ASV) control, guidance, and navigation: path following, collision avoidance, dynamic positioning, roll mitigation, and identification. Focus on MPC, observers, APF, DRL.

## Papers

### 1) Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of Autonomous Surface Vessels
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Trym Tengesdal, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2403.19028 (2024-03-27)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.19028v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.19028v1)
- Keywords: NMPC, APF, collision avoidance, anti-grounding, COLREGs, disturbance observer
- Summary: Proposes NMPC with artificial potential fields and a nonlinear disturbance observer to simultaneously handle collision avoidance, path following, and anti-grounding under wind/wave/current disturbances while incorporating COLREGs.

### 2) This is the Way: Mitigating the Roll of an Autonomous Uncrewed Surface Vessel in Wavy Conditions Using MPC
- Authors: Daniel L. Jenkins, Joshua A. Marshall
- arXiv: 2408.15349 (2024-08-27)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.15349v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.15349v1)
- Keywords: roll mitigation, NMPC, wave modeling, USV
- Summary: Develops a nonlinear MPC to reduce roll for an underactuated USV in sinusoidal waves, achieving ~39% average roll reduction in simulations with a tunable cost weighting strategy.

### 3) Digital Twin of ASVs for Safe Maritime Navigation Enabled through Predictive Modeling and RL
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Andreas Von Brandis, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2401.04032 (revised 2024-03-30)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04032v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.04032v2)
- Keywords: digital twin, NMPC safety filter, AIS/LiDAR tracking, SITAW
- Summary: Demonstrates a Unity-based DT integrating tracking (AIS + synthetic LiDAR) and a predictive safety filter (NMPC) to simulate what-if scenarios and provide optimal navigation decisions.

### 4) Digital Twin for Autonomous Surface Vessels: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2411.03465 (2024-11-05)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.03465v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.03465v1)
- Keywords: digital twin levels (0–5), autonomy, COLREGs
- Summary: Reviews DT maturity levels for ASVs and outlines how DTs underpin reliable autonomous control, including collision avoidance/path following.

### 5) Practical identification of ASV actuation dynamics with minimal instrumentation (extended)
- Authors: Thalia Morel, Luis Orihuela, Christophe Combastel, Guillermo Bejarano
- arXiv: 2410.00631 (2024-10-01)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.00631v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.00631v2)
- Keywords: system identification, grey-box, propeller model, inertia matrix
- Summary: Grey-box modeling to identify propeller and vessel inertial parameters using only position, heading, and PWM—no IMU—achieving R^2 > 0.94 for velocities.

### 6) Deep RL Based Tracking Control of an ASV in Natural Waters
- Authors: Wei Wang et al.
- arXiv: 2302.08100 (ICRA 2023)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08100v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.08100v2)
- Keywords: DRL vs NMPC, disturbance rejection, field experiments
- Summary: DRL controller trained in simulation shows 35–53% lower tracking error than NMPC in both simulated and natural waters, indicating better disturbance rejection.

### 7) Collision Avoidance for ASVs using Novel Artificial Potential Fields
- Authors: Aditya K. Jadhav et al.
- arXiv: 2310.05567 (2023-10-09)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05567v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.05567v1)
- Keywords: harmonic APF, COLREGs, dynamic obstacles
- Summary: Introduces harmonic-function-based APFs for robust obstacle avoidance with COLREGs compliance; outperforms classical APF and velocity obstacles in Monte Carlo trials.

### 8) Hybrid Simulation–Experiment Test Platform for Dynamic Positioning Vessels
- Authors: Changjun Hu et al.
- arXiv: 2210.12621 (2022-10-23)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12621v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.12621v1)
- Keywords: dynamic positioning (DP), 6-DOF, Froude scaling
- Summary: Presents a DP test platform unifying high-fidelity hydro simulations with scaled experiments to shorten tuning cycles and validate controllers.

### 9) Flatness-Based Trajectory Planning and MPC for Underactuated MSVs
- Authors: Max Lutz, Thomas Meurer
- arXiv: 2101.12730 (ACC 2021)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.12730v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.12730v1)
- Keywords: differential flatness, MPC, obstacle constraints
- Summary: Uses flat outputs to simplify NMPC for underactuated vessels, enabling long horizons and nonuniform sampling; includes obstacle and input constraints.

### 10) Observer-Based Path Following under Constant Unknown Currents (Global)
- Authors: Belleter et al.
- arXiv: 1810.06974 (2018-10-11)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.06974v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.06974v1)
- Keywords: ocean current observer, global asymptotic stability
- Summary: Proposes a path-tangential frame and ocean-current observer to guarantee global asymptotic stability of path-following errors for underactuated vessels.

## Thematic Takeaways
- NMPC remains central for ASV navigation (collision avoidance, roll mitigation, docking) and integrates well with observers and safety filters.
- Digital twins are increasingly used to de-risk algorithm deployment and to enable predictive and prescriptive autonomy.
- DRL shows promising tracking performance vs. NMPC in field trials, but interpretability and safety guarantees remain challenges.
- System identification with minimal sensors helps bootstrap models for control when instrumentation is limited.
- Classical guidance/observer designs continue to provide strong guarantees in currents and underactuation.

## Suggested Next Steps
- Compare NMPC vs DRL on your vessel model with shared scenarios and metrics.
- Incorporate COLREGs-compliant APFs with disturbance observers.
- Build a DT pipeline (AIS/LiDAR ingestion) to evaluate what-if cases before sea trials.
"}]}

我可以联网帮你查最新数据，不过刚才直接打开部分权威页面（搜索引擎结果、浙江大学本科招生网、阳光高考等）时遇到反爬或连接限制，没能直接获取到具体分数与位次。

为避免误差，先确认两点：
1) 你想查的是本科高考录取，还是研究生（推免/统考）？
2) 若是本科，请提供：省份、选科要求（物理等）、想看的口径（投档线/位次/最高-最低-平均分/招生计划数）。我就能定向抓取对应省考试院或浙大本科招生网的页面给你精确数据。

同时给你几条权威查询路径（你也可把页面链接发我，我来代查）：
- 浙江大学本科招生网（各省投档线/分数线/计划）：bkzs.zju.edu.cn（有时需从首页导航“录取查询/各省分数线”进入）
- 各省教育考试院官网（“本科批投档线/录取统计”栏目）
- 阳光高考平台（高校分数线-浙江大学页）

背景提示（不代替具体数据）：2024年计算机类在各顶尖高校普遍竞争最激烈，浙大“信息类/计算机类”在多数省份的投档线与位次基本处在全省顶尖区间，常高于同校不少专业。具体到你所在省份和批次差异很大，建议用权威投档线和位次对照。

告诉我你的省份和想看的口径，我立即再试联网抓取并整理成清单发你。

["Title: Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of Autonomous Surface Vessels

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Trym Tengesdal, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-03-27T21:57:18Z
- Last Updated: 2024-03-27T21:57:18Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
This article proposes an approach for collision avoidance, path following, and anti-grounding of autonomous surface vessels under consideration of environmental forces based on Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC). Artificial Potential Fields (APFs) set the foundation for the cost function of the optimal control problem in terms of collision avoidance and anti-grounding. Depending on the risk of a collision given by the resulting force of the APFs, the controller optimizes regarding an adapted heading and travel speed by additionally following a desired path. For this purpose, nonlinear vessel dynamics are used for the NMPC. To extend the situational awareness concerning environmental disturbances impacted by wind, waves, and sea currents, a nonlinear disturbance observer is coupled to the entire NMPC scheme, allowing for the correction of an incorrect vessel motion due to external forces. In addition, the most essential rules according to the Convention on the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) are considered. The results of the simulations show that the proposed framework can control an autonomous surface vessel under various challenging scenarios, including environmental disturbances, to avoid collisions and follow desired paths.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.19028v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2403.19028v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.19028v1
"]

["Title: This is the Way: Mitigating the Roll of an Autonomous Uncrewed Surface Vessel in Wavy Conditions Using Model Predictive Control

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel L. Jenkins, Joshua A. Marshall
- Published: 2024-08-27T18:21:10Z
- Last Updated: 2024-08-27T18:21:10Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: eess.SY

Abstract:
Though larger vessels may be well-equipped to deal with wavy conditions, smaller vessels are often more susceptible to disturbances. This paper explores the development of a nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) system for Uncrewed Surface Vessels (USVs) in wavy conditions to minimize average roll. The NMPC is based on a prediction method that uses information about the vessel's dynamics and an assumed wave model. This method is able to mitigate the roll of an under-actuated USV in a variety of conditions by adjusting the weights of the cost function. The results show a reduction of 39% of average roll with a tuned controller in conditions with 1.75-metre sinusoidal waves. A general and intuitive tuning strategy is established. This preliminary work is a proof of concept which sets the stage for the leveraging of wave prediction methodologies to perform planning and control in real time for USVs in real-world scenarios and field trials.

- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.15349v1

["Title: Digital Twin of Autonomous Surface Vessels for Safe Maritime Navigation Enabled through Predictive Modeling and Reinforcement Learning

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Andreas Von Brandis, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-01-08T17:17:08Z
- Last Updated: 2024-03-30T10:18:12Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: eess.SY

Abstract:
Autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) play an increasingly important role in the safety and sustainability of open sea operations. Since most maritime accidents are related to human failure, intelligent algorithms for autonomous collision avoidance and path following can drastically reduce the risk in the maritime sector. A DT is a virtual representative of a real physical system and can enhance the situational awareness (SITAW) of such an ASV to generate optimal decisions. This work builds on an existing DT framework for ASVs and demonstrates foundations for enabling predictive, prescriptive, and autonomous capabilities. In this context, sophisticated target tracking approaches are crucial for estimating and predicting the position and motion of other dynamic objects. The applied tracking method is enabled by real-time automatic identification system (AIS) data and synthetic light detection and ranging (Lidar) measurements. To guarantee safety during autonomous operations, we applied a predictive safety filter, based on the concept of nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC). The approaches are implemented into a DT built with the Unity game engine. As a result, this work demonstrates the potential of a DT capable of making predictions, playing through various what-if scenarios, and providing optimal control decisions according to its enhanced SITAW.

- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04032v2
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2401.04032v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.04032v2
"]

["Title: Digital Twin for Autonomous Surface Vessels: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-11-05T19:35:23Z
- Last Updated: 2024-11-05T19:35:23Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY, Additional: cs.RO

Abstract:
Autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) are becoming increasingly significant in enhancing the safety and sustainability of maritime operations. To ensure the reliability of modern control algorithms utilized in these vessels, digital twins (DTs) provide a robust framework for conducting safe and effective simulations within a virtual environment. Digital twins are generally classified on a scale from 0 to 5, with each level representing a progression in complexity and functionality: Level 0 (Standalone) employs offline modeling techniques; Level 1 (Descriptive) integrates sensors and online modeling to enhance situational awareness; Level 2 (Diagnostic) focuses on condition monitoring and cybersecurity; Level 3 (Predictive) incorporates predictive analytics; Level 4 (Prescriptive) embeds decision-support systems; and Level 5 (Autonomous) enables advanced functionalities such as collision avoidance and path following. These digital representations not only provide insights into the vessel's current state and operational efficiency but also predict future scenarios and assess life endurance. By continuously updating with real-time sensor data, the digital twin effectively corrects modeling errors and enhances decision-making processes. Since DTs are key enablers for complex autonomous systems, this paper introduces a comprehensive methodology for establishing a digital twin framework specifically tailored for ASVs. Through a detailed literature survey, we explore existing state-of-the-art enablers across the defined levels, offering valuable recommendations for future research and development in this rapidly evolving field.

- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.03465v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2411.03465v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.03465v1
"]

["Title: Practical identification approach for the actuation dynamics of autonomous surface vehicles with minimal instrumentation: extended version

Metadata:
- Authors: Thalia Morel, Luis Orihuela, Christophe Combastel, Guillermo Bejarano
- Published: 2024-10-01T12:27:47Z
- Last Updated: 2024-10-10T07:17:41Z
- Categories: Primary: math.DS, Additional: eess.SY
- DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2024.120098

Abstract:
A practical method for identifying the propeller model and inertia matrix of a marine Autonomous Surface Vehicle (ASV) is proposed in this work. Special attention is paid to limiting the instrumentation requirements. Based on a generic grey-box dynamic modelling addressing the considered catamaran-shaped ASV architecture, the static/dynamic behaviour of both propellers and the vessel dynamic are jointly estimated using the sole measurements of position, heading, and propellers pulse width modulation (PWM) signals. No accelerometer is required. Two distinct grey-box configurations involving either a static polynomial or a dynamic modelling of each propeller are proposed and compared. The resulting ASV identification methodology is shown to provide insight into the whole vessel inertial characteristics, which are key enablers in the development of autonomous navigation and control systems. Model validation was performed using data collected from the reported experiments. Model prediction errors related to both linear velocities and yaw rate are evaluated and compared based on given metrics. The results underscore the robustness and accuracy of the identified models in capturing the essential dynamics of the ASV, with a determination coefficient that consistently exceeds 0.94 for all estimated velocities.

- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2024.120098
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2410.00631v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.00631v2
"]

["Title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Tracking Control of an Autonomous Surface Vessel in Natural Waters

Metadata:
- Authors: Wei Wang, Xiaojing Cao, Alejandro Gonzalez-Garcia, Lianhao Yin, Niklas Hagemann, Yuanyuan Qiao, Carlo Ratti, Daniela Rus
- Published: 2023-02-16T05:50:07Z
- Last Updated: 2023-02-20T19:26:40Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO

Abstract:
Accurate control of autonomous marine robots still poses challenges due to the complex dynamics of the environment. In this paper, we propose a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) approach to train a controller for autonomous surface vessel (ASV) trajectory tracking and compare its performance with an advanced nonlinear model predictive controller (NMPC) in real environments. Taking into account environmental disturbances (e.g., wind, waves, and currents), noisy measurements, and non-ideal actuators presented in the physical ASV, several effective reward functions for DRL tracking control policies are carefully designed. The control policies were trained in a simulation environment with diverse tracking trajectories and disturbances. The performance of the DRL controller has been verified and compared with the NMPC in both simulations with model-based environmental disturbances and in natural waters. Simulations show that the DRL controller has 53.33% lower tracking error than that of NMPC. Experimental results further show that, compared to NMPC, the DRL controller has 35.51% lower tracking error, indicating that DRL controllers offer better disturbance rejection in river environments than NMPC.

- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08100v2
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2302.08100v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.08100v2

Additional Information:
- Comment: ICRA 2023
"]

["Title: Collision Avoidance for Autonomous Surface Vessels using Novel Artificial Potential Fields

Metadata:
- Authors: Aditya Kailas Jadhav, Anantha Raj Pandi, Abhilash Somayajula
- Published: 2023-10-09T09:43:36Z
- Last Updated: 2023-10-09T09:43:36Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: cs.CE, eess.SY
- DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2023.116011
- Journal Reference: Ocean Engineering, 288 (2023), 116011

Abstract:
As the demand for transportation through waterways continues to rise, the number of vessels plying the waters has correspondingly increased. This has resulted in a greater number of accidents and collisions between ships, some of which lead to significant loss of life and financial losses. Research has shown that human error is a major factor responsible for such incidents. The maritime industry is constantly exploring newer approaches to autonomy to mitigate this issue. This study presents the use of novel Artificial Potential Fields (APFs) to perform obstacle and collision avoidance in marine environments. This study highlights the advantage of harmonic functions over traditional functions in modeling potential fields. With a modification, the method is extended to effectively avoid dynamic obstacles while adhering to COLREGs. Improved performance is observed as compared to the traditional potential fields and also against the popular velocity obstacle approach. A comprehensive statistical analysis is also performed through Monte Carlo simulations in different congested environments that emulate real traffic conditions to demonstrate robustness of the approach.

["Title: Development of a Hybrid Simulation and Experiment Test Platform for Dynamic Positioning Vessels

Metadata:
- Authors: Changjun Hu, Quan Shi, Xin Li, Xiaoxian Guo
- Published: 2022-10-23T05:32:26Z
- Last Updated: 2022-10-23T05:32:26Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
The harsh ocean environment and complex operating condition require high dynamic positioning (DP) capability of offshore vessel. The design, development and performance evaluation of DP system are generally carried out by numerical simulations or scale model experiments. Compared with the time-consuming and laborious experiment, the simulation is convenient and low cost, but its results lack practical reference due to oversimplification of the model. Therefore, this paper presents a hybrid simulation and experiment test platform for DP vessels. Its characteristics are: the realistic calculation of environmental loads and motion response, the consistency of algorithms and parameters for simulation and experiment greatly shortening the time of experiment adjusting, switchable and online renewable controller facilitating algorithm testing. The test platform can test the performance of DP system and determine the operational time window. In the hydrodynamic simulation, the six degree-of-freedom model is used to describe the dynamic response of the DP vessel, considering the fluid memory effect and frequency-dependent hydrodynamic parameters. In the experiment, the similarity theory based on the same Froude number is used to ensure the consistency of control parameters with simulation. Finally, a case study of DP shuttle tanker is used to verify the credibility of the test platform.

- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2210.12621v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.12621v1
"]

["Title: Optimal Trajectory Planning and Model Predictive Control of Underactuated Marine Surface Vessels using a Flatness-Based Approach

Metadata:
- Authors: Max Lutz, Thomas Meurer
- Published: 2021-01-29T18:42:47Z
- Last Updated: 2021-01-29T18:42:47Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY, Additional: math.OC
- DOI: 10.23919/ACC50511.2021.9483265

Abstract:
This paper demonstrates a refined approach to solving dynamic optimization problems for underactuated marine surface vessels. To this end the differential flatness of a mathematical model assuming full actuation is exploited to derive an efficient representation of a finite dimensional nonlinear programming problem, which in turn is constrained to apply to the underactuated case. It is illustrated how the properties of the flat output can be employed for the generation of an initial guess to be used in the optimization algorithm in the presence of static and dynamic obstacles. As an example energy optimal point to point trajectory planning for a nonlinear 3 degrees of freedom dynamic model of an underactuated surface vessel is undertaken. Input constraints, both in rate and magnitude as well as state constraints due to convex and non-convex obstacles in the area of operation are considered and simulation results for a challenging scenario are reported. Furthermore, an extension to a trajectory tracking controller using model predictive control is made where the benefits of the flatness based direct method allow to introduce nonuniform sample times that help to realize long prediction horizons while maintaining short term accuracy and real time capability. This is also verified in simulation where additional disturbances in the form of environmental disturbances, dynamic obstacles and parameter mismatch are introduced.

Additional Information:

["Title: Observer Based Path Following for Underactuated Marine Vessels in the Presence of Ocean Currents: A Global Approach - With proofs

Metadata:
- Authors: D. J. W. Belleter, M. Maghenem, C. Paliotta, K. Y. Pettersen
- Published: 2018-10-11T21:03:15Z
- Last Updated: 2018-10-11T21:03:15Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
In this paper a solution to the problem of following a curved path in the presence of a constant unknown ocean current disturbance is presented. We introduce a path variable that represents the curvilinear abscissa on the path which is used to propagate the path-tangential reference frame. The proposed dynamic update law of the path variable is non singular and the guidance law is designed such that the vessel can reject constant unknown ocean currents by using an ocean current observer. It is shown that the closed-loop system composed of the guidance law, controller and observer provides globally asymptotically stable and locally exponentially stable path following errors. The sway velocity dynamics is analyzed and, under adequate hypothesis on the path curvature, it is shown that the dynamics are well behaved and that the guidance law to exist. Simulations are presented to verify the theoretical findings.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.06974v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/1810.06974v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.06974v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:1704.00573
"]

function.name: notion-create-pages
function.arguments:
{"pages":[{"content":"# Marine Ship Control: Selected arXiv Papers (Control Systems)

## Scope
Autonomous surface vessel (ASV) control, guidance, and navigation: path following, collision avoidance, dynamic positioning, roll mitigation, and identification. Focus on MPC, observers, APF, DRL.

## Papers

### 1) Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of Autonomous Surface Vessels
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Trym Tengesdal, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2403.19028 (2024-03-27)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.19028v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.19028v1)
- Keywords: NMPC, APF, collision avoidance, anti-grounding, COLREGs, disturbance observer
- Summary: Proposes NMPC with artificial potential fields and a nonlinear disturbance observer to simultaneously handle collision avoidance, path following, and anti-grounding under wind/wave/current disturbances while incorporating COLREGs.

### 2) This is the Way: Mitigating the Roll of an Autonomous Uncrewed Surface Vessel in Wavy Conditions Using MPC
- Authors: Daniel L. Jenkins, Joshua A. Marshall
- arXiv: 2408.15349 (2024-08-27)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.15349v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.15349v1)
- Keywords: roll mitigation, NMPC, wave modeling, USV
- Summary: Develops a nonlinear MPC to reduce roll for an underactuated USV in sinusoidal waves, achieving ~39% average roll reduction in simulations with a tunable cost weighting strategy.

### 3) Digital Twin of ASVs for Safe Maritime Navigation Enabled through Predictive Modeling and RL
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Andreas Von Brandis, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2401.04032 (revised 2024-03-30)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04032v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.04032v2)
- Keywords: digital twin, NMPC safety filter, AIS/LiDAR tracking, SITAW
- Summary: Demonstrates a Unity-based DT integrating tracking (AIS + synthetic LiDAR) and a predictive safety filter (NMPC) to simulate what-if scenarios and provide optimal navigation decisions.

### 4) Digital Twin for Autonomous Surface Vessels: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2411.03465 (2024-11-05)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.03465v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.03465v1)
- Keywords: digital twin levels (0–5), autonomy, COLREGs
- Summary: Reviews DT maturity levels for ASVs and outlines how DTs underpin reliable autonomous control, including collision avoidance/path following.

### 5) Practical identification of ASV actuation dynamics with minimal instrumentation (extended)
- Authors: Thalia Morel, Luis Orihuela, Christophe Combastel, Guillermo Bejarano
- arXiv: 2410.00631 (2024-10-01)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.00631v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.00631v2)
- Keywords: system identification, grey-box, propeller model, inertia matrix
- Summary: Grey-box modeling to identify propeller and vessel inertial parameters using only position, heading, and PWM—no IMU—achieving R^2 > 0.94 for velocities.

### 6) Deep RL Based Tracking Control of an ASV in Natural Waters
- Authors: Wei Wang et al.
- arXiv: 2302.08100 (ICRA 2023)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08100v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.08100v2)
- Keywords: DRL vs NMPC, disturbance rejection, field experiments
- Summary: DRL controller trained in simulation shows 35–53% lower tracking error than NMPC in both simulated and natural waters, indicating better disturbance rejection.

### 7) Collision Avoidance for ASVs using Novel Artificial Potential Fields
- Authors: Aditya K. Jadhav et al.
- arXiv: 2310.05567 (2023-10-09)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05567v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.05567v1)
- Keywords: harmonic APF, COLREGs, dynamic obstacles
- Summary: Introduces harmonic-function-based APFs for robust obstacle avoidance with COLREGs compliance; outperforms classical APF and velocity obstacles in Monte Carlo trials.

### 8) Hybrid Simulation–Experiment Test Platform for Dynamic Positioning Vessels
- Authors: Changjun Hu et al.
- arXiv: 2210.12621 (2022-10-23)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12621v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.12621v1)
- Keywords: dynamic positioning (DP), 6-DOF, Froude scaling
- Summary: Presents a DP test platform unifying high-fidelity hydro simulations with scaled experiments to shorten tuning cycles and validate controllers.

### 9) Flatness-Based Trajectory Planning and MPC for Underactuated MSVs
- Authors: Max Lutz, Thomas Meurer
- arXiv: 2101.12730 (ACC 2021)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.12730v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.12730v1)
- Keywords: differential flatness, MPC, obstacle constraints
- Summary: Uses flat outputs to simplify NMPC for underactuated vessels, enabling long horizons and nonuniform sampling; includes obstacle and input constraints.

### 10) Observer-Based Path Following under Constant Unknown Currents (Global)
- Authors: Belleter et al.
- arXiv: 1810.06974 (2018-10-11)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.06974v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.06974v1)
- Keywords: ocean current observer, global asymptotic stability
- Summary: Proposes a path-tangential frame and ocean-current observer to guarantee global asymptotic stability of path-following errors for underactuated vessels.

## Thematic Takeaways
- NMPC remains central for ASV navigation (collision avoidance, roll mitigation, docking) and integrates well with observers and safety filters.
- Digital twins are increasingly used to de-risk algorithm deployment and to enable predictive and prescriptive autonomy.
- DRL shows promising tracking performance vs. NMPC in field trials, but interpretability and safety guarantees remain challenges.
- System identification with minimal sensors helps bootstrap models for control when instrumentation is limited.
- Classical guidance/observer designs continue to provide strong guarantees in currents and underactuation.

## Suggested Next Steps
- Compare NMPC vs DRL on your vessel model with shared scenarios and metrics.
- Incorporate COLREGs-compliant APFs with disturbance observers.
- Build a DT pipeline (AIS/LiDAR ingestion) to evaluate what-if cases before sea trials.
"}]}

I found and summarized relevant arXiv papers on marine ship/ASV control and created a Notion page with the highlights. Here’s what I added:

Title: Marine Ship Control: Selected arXiv Papers (Control Systems)
- Coverage: ASV control, guidance, navigation; NMPC, observers, APF, DRL; dynamic positioning; roll mitigation; system identification.
- Key papers included:
  - Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of ASVs (arXiv:2403.19028, 2024)
  - Mitigating Roll of USVs in Waves using MPC (arXiv:2408.15349, 2024)
  - Digital Twin of ASVs with Predictive Modeling and RL (arXiv:2401.04032, 2024)
  - Digital Twin for ASVs: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation (arXiv:2411.03465, 2024)
  - Minimal-instrumentation identification of ASV actuation dynamics (arXiv:2410.00631, 2024)
  - DRL-based tracking control of ASVs vs NMPC (arXiv:2302.08100, ICRA 2023)
  - APF-based collision avoidance for ASVs with COLREGs (arXiv:2310.05567, 2023)
  - Hybrid simulation–experiment DP platform (arXiv:2210.12621, 2022)
  - Flatness-based trajectory planning and MPC for underactuated vessels (arXiv:2101.12730, ACC 2021)
  - Observer-based path following under unknown currents (arXiv:1810.06974)

Notion page link:
- https://www.notion.so/2c3b93bb159c81cfa440e536fd458150

If you want, I can refine this by:
- Filtering only 2023–2025 papers or adding dynamic positioning/docking specific works.
- Adding a comparison table (method, guarantees, environment, main results).
- Pulling PDFs and attaching them to the Notion page.

我可以联网帮你查最新数据，不过刚才直接打开部分权威页面（搜索引擎结果、浙江大学本科招生网、阳光高考等）时遇到反爬或连接限制，没能直接获取到具体分数与位次。

为避免误差，先确认两点：
1) 你想查的是本科高考录取，还是研究生（推免/统考）？
2) 若是本科，请提供：省份、选科要求（物理等）、想看的口径（投档线/位次/最高-最低-平均分/招生计划数）。我就能定向抓取对应省考试院或浙大本科招生网的页面给你精确数据。

同时给你几条权威查询路径（你也可把页面链接发我，我来代查）：
- 浙江大学本科招生网（各省投档线/分数线/计划）：bkzs.zju.edu.cn（有时需从首页导航“录取查询/各省分数线”进入）
- 各省教育考试院官网（“本科批投档线/录取统计”栏目）
- 阳光高考平台（高校分数线-浙江大学页）

背景提示（不代替具体数据）：2024年计算机类在各顶尖高校普遍竞争最激烈，浙大“信息类/计算机类”在多数省份的投档线与位次基本处在全省顶尖区间，常高于同校不少专业。具体到你所在省份和批次差异很大，建议用权威投档线和位次对照。

告诉我你的省份和想看的口径，我立即再试联网抓取并整理成清单发你。

["Title: Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of Autonomous Surface Vessels

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Trym Tengesdal, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-03-27T21:57:18Z
- Last Updated: 2024-03-27T21:57:18Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
This article proposes an approach for collision avoidance, path following, and anti-grounding of autonomous surface vessels under consideration of environmental forces based on Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC). Artificial Potential Fields (APFs) set the foundation for the cost function of the optimal control problem in terms of collision avoidance and anti-grounding. Depending on the risk of a collision given by the resulting force of the APFs, the controller optimizes regarding an adapted heading and travel speed by additionally following a desired path. For this purpose, nonlinear vessel dynamics are used for the NMPC. To extend the situational awareness concerning environmental disturbances impacted by wind, waves, and sea currents, a nonlinear disturbance observer is coupled to the entire NMPC scheme, allowing for the correction of an incorrect vessel motion due to external forces. In addition, the most essential rules according to the Convention on the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) are considered. The results of the simulations show that the proposed framework can control an autonomous surface vessel under various challenging scenarios, including environmental disturbances, to avoid collisions and follow desired paths.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.19028v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2403.19028v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.19028v1
"]

["Title: This is the Way: Mitigating the Roll of an Autonomous Uncrewed Surface Vessel in Wavy Conditions Using Model Predictive Control

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel L. Jenkins, Joshua A. Marshall
- Published: 2024-08-27T18:21:10Z
- Last Updated: 2024-08-27T18:21:10Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: eess.SY

Abstract:
Though larger vessels may be well-equipped to deal with wavy conditions, smaller vessels are often more susceptible to disturbances. This paper explores the development of a nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) system for Uncrewed Surface Vessels (USVs) in wavy conditions to minimize average roll. The NMPC is based on a prediction method that uses information about the vessel's dynamics and an assumed wave model. This method is able to mitigate the roll of an under-actuated USV in a variety of conditions by adjusting the weights of the cost function. The results show a reduction of 39% of average roll with a tuned controller in conditions with 1.75-metre sinusoidal waves. A general and intuitive tuning strategy is established. This preliminary work is a proof of concept which sets the stage for the leveraging of wave prediction methodologies to perform planning and control in real time for USVs in real-world scenarios and field trials.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.15349v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2408.15349v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.15349v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: 6 pages, 10 figures. To appear in Proceedings of the 2024 IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Robots and Systems (IROS), October 2024
"]

["Title: Digital Twin of Autonomous Surface Vessels for Safe Maritime Navigation Enabled through Predictive Modeling and Reinforcement Learning

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Andreas Von Brandis, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-01-08T17:17:08Z
- Last Updated: 2024-03-30T10:18:12Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: eess.SY

Abstract:
Autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) play an increasingly important role in the safety and sustainability of open sea operations. Since most maritime accidents are related to human failure, intelligent algorithms for autonomous collision avoidance and path following can drastically reduce the risk in the maritime sector. A DT is a virtual representative of a real physical system and can enhance the situational awareness (SITAW) of such an ASV to generate optimal decisions. This work builds on an existing DT framework for ASVs and demonstrates foundations for enabling predictive, prescriptive, and autonomous capabilities. In this context, sophisticated target tracking approaches are crucial for estimating and predicting the position and motion of other dynamic objects. The applied tracking method is enabled by real-time automatic identification system (AIS) data and synthetic light detection and ranging (Lidar) measurements. To guarantee safety during autonomous operations, we applied a predictive safety filter, based on the concept of nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC). The approaches are implemented into a DT built with the Unity game engine. As a result, this work demonstrates the potential of a DT capable of making predictions, playing through various what-if scenarios, and providing optimal control decisions according to its enhanced SITAW.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04032v2
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2401.04032v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.04032v2
"]

["Title: Digital Twin for Autonomous Surface Vessels: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation

Metadata:
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Adil Rasheed
- Published: 2024-11-05T19:35:23Z
- Last Updated: 2024-11-05T19:35:23Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY, Additional: cs.RO

Abstract:
Autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) are becoming increasingly significant in enhancing the safety and sustainability of maritime operations. To ensure the reliability of modern control algorithms utilized in these vessels, digital twins (DTs) provide a robust framework for conducting safe and effective simulations within a virtual environment. Digital twins are generally classified on a scale from 0 to 5, with each level representing a progression in complexity and functionality: Level 0 (Standalone) employs offline modeling techniques; Level 1 (Descriptive) integrates sensors and online modeling to enhance situational awareness; Level 2 (Diagnostic) focuses on condition monitoring and cybersecurity; Level 3 (Predictive) incorporates predictive analytics; Level 4 (Prescriptive) embeds decision-support systems; and Level 5 (Autonomous) enables advanced functionalities such as collision avoidance and path following. These digital representations not only provide insights into the vessel's current state and operational efficiency but also predict future scenarios and assess life endurance. By continuously updating with real-time sensor data, the digital twin effectively corrects modeling errors and enhances decision-making processes. Since DTs are key enablers for complex autonomous systems, this paper introduces a comprehensive methodology for establishing a digital twin framework specifically tailored for ASVs. Through a detailed literature survey, we explore existing state-of-the-art enablers across the defined levels, offering valuable recommendations for future research and development in this rapidly evolving field.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.03465v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2411.03465v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.03465v1
"]

["Title: Practical identification approach for the actuation dynamics of autonomous surface vehicles with minimal instrumentation: extended version

Metadata:
- Authors: Thalia Morel, Luis Orihuela, Christophe Combastel, Guillermo Bejarano
- Published: 2024-10-01T12:27:47Z
- Last Updated: 2024-10-10T07:17:41Z
- Categories: Primary: math.DS, Additional: eess.SY
- DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2024.120098

Abstract:
A practical method for identifying the propeller model and inertia matrix of a marine Autonomous Surface Vehicle (ASV) is proposed in this work. Special attention is paid to limiting the instrumentation requirements. Based on a generic grey-box dynamic modelling addressing the considered catamaran-shaped ASV architecture, the static/dynamic behaviour of both propellers and the vessel dynamic are jointly estimated using the sole measurements of position, heading, and propellers pulse width modulation (PWM) signals. No accelerometer is required. Two distinct grey-box configurations involving either a static polynomial or a dynamic modelling of each propeller are proposed and compared. The resulting ASV identification methodology is shown to provide insight into the whole vessel inertial characteristics, which are key enablers in the development of autonomous navigation and control systems. Model validation was performed using data collected from the reported experiments. Model prediction errors related to both linear velocities and yaw rate are evaluated and compared based on given metrics. The results underscore the robustness and accuracy of the identified models in capturing the essential dynamics of the ASV, with a determination coefficient that consistently exceeds 0.94 for all estimated velocities.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2024.120098
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2410.00631v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.00631v2
"]

["Title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Tracking Control of an Autonomous Surface Vessel in Natural Waters

Metadata:
- Authors: Wei Wang, Xiaojing Cao, Alejandro Gonzalez-Garcia, Lianhao Yin, Niklas Hagemann, Yuanyuan Qiao, Carlo Ratti, Daniela Rus
- Published: 2023-02-16T05:50:07Z
- Last Updated: 2023-02-20T19:26:40Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO

Abstract:
Accurate control of autonomous marine robots still poses challenges due to the complex dynamics of the environment. In this paper, we propose a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) approach to train a controller for autonomous surface vessel (ASV) trajectory tracking and compare its performance with an advanced nonlinear model predictive controller (NMPC) in real environments. Taking into account environmental disturbances (e.g., wind, waves, and currents), noisy measurements, and non-ideal actuators presented in the physical ASV, several effective reward functions for DRL tracking control policies are carefully designed. The control policies were trained in a simulation environment with diverse tracking trajectories and disturbances. The performance of the DRL controller has been verified and compared with the NMPC in both simulations with model-based environmental disturbances and in natural waters. Simulations show that the DRL controller has 53.33% lower tracking error than that of NMPC. Experimental results further show that, compared to NMPC, the DRL controller has 35.51% lower tracking error, indicating that DRL controllers offer better disturbance rejection in river environments than NMPC.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08100v2
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2302.08100v2
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.08100v2

Additional Information:
- Comment: ICRA 2023
"]

["Title: Collision Avoidance for Autonomous Surface Vessels using Novel Artificial Potential Fields

Metadata:
- Authors: Aditya Kailas Jadhav, Anantha Raj Pandi, Abhilash Somayajula
- Published: 2023-10-09T09:43:36Z
- Last Updated: 2023-10-09T09:43:36Z
- Categories: Primary: cs.RO, Additional: cs.CE, eess.SY
- DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2023.116011
- Journal Reference: Ocean Engineering, 288 (2023), 116011

Abstract:
As the demand for transportation through waterways continues to rise, the number of vessels plying the waters has correspondingly increased. This has resulted in a greater number of accidents and collisions between ships, some of which lead to significant loss of life and financial losses. Research has shown that human error is a major factor responsible for such incidents. The maritime industry is constantly exploring newer approaches to autonomy to mitigate this issue. This study presents the use of novel Artificial Potential Fields (APFs) to perform obstacle and collision avoidance in marine environments. This study highlights the advantage of harmonic functions over traditional functions in modeling potential fields. With a modification, the method is extended to effectively avoid dynamic obstacles while adhering to COLREGs. Improved performance is observed as compared to the traditional potential fields and also against the popular velocity obstacle approach. A comprehensive statistical analysis is also performed through Monte Carlo simulations in different congested environments that emulate real traffic conditions to demonstrate robustness of the approach.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2023.116011
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2310.05567v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.05567v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: 28 pages, 30 figures
"]

["Title: Development of a Hybrid Simulation and Experiment Test Platform for Dynamic Positioning Vessels

Metadata:
- Authors: Changjun Hu, Quan Shi, Xin Li, Xiaoxian Guo
- Published: 2022-10-23T05:32:26Z
- Last Updated: 2022-10-23T05:32:26Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
The harsh ocean environment and complex operating condition require high dynamic positioning (DP) capability of offshore vessel. The design, development and performance evaluation of DP system are generally carried out by numerical simulations or scale model experiments. Compared with the time-consuming and laborious experiment, the simulation is convenient and low cost, but its results lack practical reference due to oversimplification of the model. Therefore, this paper presents a hybrid simulation and experiment test platform for DP vessels. Its characteristics are: the realistic calculation of environmental loads and motion response, the consistency of algorithms and parameters for simulation and experiment greatly shortening the time of experiment adjusting, switchable and online renewable controller facilitating algorithm testing. The test platform can test the performance of DP system and determine the operational time window. In the hydrodynamic simulation, the six degree-of-freedom model is used to describe the dynamic response of the DP vessel, considering the fluid memory effect and frequency-dependent hydrodynamic parameters. In the experiment, the similarity theory based on the same Froude number is used to ensure the consistency of control parameters with simulation. Finally, a case study of DP shuttle tanker is used to verify the credibility of the test platform.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12621v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2210.12621v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.12621v1
"]

["Title: Optimal Trajectory Planning and Model Predictive Control of Underactuated Marine Surface Vessels using a Flatness-Based Approach

Metadata:
- Authors: Max Lutz, Thomas Meurer
- Published: 2021-01-29T18:42:47Z
- Last Updated: 2021-01-29T18:42:47Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY, Additional: math.OC
- DOI: 10.23919/ACC50511.2021.9483265

Abstract:
This paper demonstrates a refined approach to solving dynamic optimization problems for underactuated marine surface vessels. To this end the differential flatness of a mathematical model assuming full actuation is exploited to derive an efficient representation of a finite dimensional nonlinear programming problem, which in turn is constrained to apply to the underactuated case. It is illustrated how the properties of the flat output can be employed for the generation of an initial guess to be used in the optimization algorithm in the presence of static and dynamic obstacles. As an example energy optimal point to point trajectory planning for a nonlinear 3 degrees of freedom dynamic model of an underactuated surface vessel is undertaken. Input constraints, both in rate and magnitude as well as state constraints due to convex and non-convex obstacles in the area of operation are considered and simulation results for a challenging scenario are reported. Furthermore, an extension to a trajectory tracking controller using model predictive control is made where the benefits of the flatness based direct method allow to introduce nonuniform sample times that help to realize long prediction horizons while maintaining short term accuracy and real time capability. This is also verified in simulation where additional disturbances in the form of environmental disturbances, dynamic obstacles and parameter mismatch are introduced.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://doi.org/10.23919/ACC50511.2021.9483265
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/2101.12730v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.12730v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: Accepted for presentation at, and publication in the proceedings of, the 2021 American Control Conference (ACC)
"]

["Title: Observer Based Path Following for Underactuated Marine Vessels in the Presence of Ocean Currents: A Global Approach - With proofs

Metadata:
- Authors: D. J. W. Belleter, M. Maghenem, C. Paliotta, K. Y. Pettersen
- Published: 2018-10-11T21:03:15Z
- Last Updated: 2018-10-11T21:03:15Z
- Categories: Primary: eess.SY

Abstract:
In this paper a solution to the problem of following a curved path in the presence of a constant unknown ocean current disturbance is presented. We introduce a path variable that represents the curvilinear abscissa on the path which is used to propagate the path-tangential reference frame. The proposed dynamic update law of the path variable is non singular and the guidance law is designed such that the vessel can reject constant unknown ocean currents by using an ocean current observer. It is shown that the closed-loop system composed of the guidance law, controller and observer provides globally asymptotically stable and locally exponentially stable path following errors. The sway velocity dynamics is analyzed and, under adequate hypothesis on the path curvature, it is shown that the dynamics are well behaved and that the guidance law to exist. Simulations are presented to verify the theoretical findings.

Access Options:
- Abstract page: https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.06974v1
- Full text HTML version: https://arxiv.org/html/1810.06974v1
- PDF version: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.06974v1

Additional Information:
- Comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:1704.00573
"]

function.name: notion-create-pages
function.arguments:
{"pages":[{"content":"# Marine Ship Control: Selected arXiv Papers (Control Systems)

## Scope
Autonomous surface vessel (ASV) control, guidance, and navigation: path following, collision avoidance, dynamic positioning, roll mitigation, and identification. Focus on MPC, observers, APF, DRL.

## Papers

### 1) Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Enhanced Navigation of Autonomous Surface Vessels
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Trym Tengesdal, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2403.19028 (2024-03-27)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.19028v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.19028v1)
- Keywords: NMPC, APF, collision avoidance, anti-grounding, COLREGs, disturbance observer
- Summary: Proposes NMPC with artificial potential fields and a nonlinear disturbance observer to simultaneously handle collision avoidance, path following, and anti-grounding under wind/wave/current disturbances while incorporating COLREGs.

### 2) This is the Way: Mitigating the Roll of an Autonomous Uncrewed Surface Vessel in Wavy Conditions Using MPC
- Authors: Daniel L. Jenkins, Joshua A. Marshall
- arXiv: 2408.15349 (2024-08-27)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.15349v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.15349v1)
- Keywords: roll mitigation, NMPC, wave modeling, USV
- Summary: Develops a nonlinear MPC to reduce roll for an underactuated USV in sinusoidal waves, achieving ~39% average roll reduction in simulations with a tunable cost weighting strategy.

### 3) Digital Twin of ASVs for Safe Maritime Navigation Enabled through Predictive Modeling and RL
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Andreas Von Brandis, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2401.04032 (revised 2024-03-30)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04032v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2401.04032v2)
- Keywords: digital twin, NMPC safety filter, AIS/LiDAR tracking, SITAW
- Summary: Demonstrates a Unity-based DT integrating tracking (AIS + synthetic LiDAR) and a predictive safety filter (NMPC) to simulate what-if scenarios and provide optimal navigation decisions.

### 4) Digital Twin for Autonomous Surface Vessels: Enabler for Safe Maritime Navigation
- Authors: Daniel Menges, Adil Rasheed
- arXiv: 2411.03465 (2024-11-05)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.03465v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.03465v1)
- Keywords: digital twin levels (0–5), autonomy, COLREGs
- Summary: Reviews DT maturity levels for ASVs and outlines how DTs underpin reliable autonomous control, including collision avoidance/path following.

### 5) Practical identification of ASV actuation dynamics with minimal instrumentation (extended)
- Authors: Thalia Morel, Luis Orihuela, Christophe Combastel, Guillermo Bejarano
- arXiv: 2410.00631 (2024-10-01)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.00631v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.00631v2)
- Keywords: system identification, grey-box, propeller model, inertia matrix
- Summary: Grey-box modeling to identify propeller and vessel inertial parameters using only position, heading, and PWM—no IMU—achieving R^2 > 0.94 for velocities.

### 6) Deep RL Based Tracking Control of an ASV in Natural Waters
- Authors: Wei Wang et al.
- arXiv: 2302.08100 (ICRA 2023)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08100v2) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.08100v2)
- Keywords: DRL vs NMPC, disturbance rejection, field experiments
- Summary: DRL controller trained in simulation shows 35–53% lower tracking error than NMPC in both simulated and natural waters, indicating better disturbance rejection.

### 7) Collision Avoidance for ASVs using Novel Artificial Potential Fields
- Authors: Aditya K. Jadhav et al.
- arXiv: 2310.05567 (2023-10-09)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05567v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.05567v1)
- Keywords: harmonic APF, COLREGs, dynamic obstacles
- Summary: Introduces harmonic-function-based APFs for robust obstacle avoidance with COLREGs compliance; outperforms classical APF and velocity obstacles in Monte Carlo trials.

### 8) Hybrid Simulation–Experiment Test Platform for Dynamic Positioning Vessels
- Authors: Changjun Hu et al.
- arXiv: 2210.12621 (2022-10-23)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12621v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.12621v1)
- Keywords: dynamic positioning (DP), 6-DOF, Froude scaling
- Summary: Presents a DP test platform unifying high-fidelity hydro simulations with scaled experiments to shorten tuning cycles and validate controllers.

### 9) Flatness-Based Trajectory Planning and MPC for Underactuated MSVs
- Authors: Max Lutz, Thomas Meurer
- arXiv: 2101.12730 (ACC 2021)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.12730v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.12730v1)
- Keywords: differential flatness, MPC, obstacle constraints
- Summary: Uses flat outputs to simplify NMPC for underactuated vessels, enabling long horizons and nonuniform sampling; includes obstacle and input constraints.

### 10) Observer-Based Path Following under Constant Unknown Currents (Global)
- Authors: Belleter et al.
- arXiv: 1810.06974 (2018-10-11)
- Links: [Abs](https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.06974v1) | [PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.06974v1)
- Keywords: ocean current observer, global asymptotic stability
- Summary: Proposes a path-tangential frame and ocean-current observer to guarantee global asymptotic stability of path-following errors for underactuated vessels.

## Thematic Takeaways
- NMPC remains central for ASV navigation (collision avoidance, roll mitigation, docking) and integrates well with observers and safety filters.
- Digital twins are increasingly used to de-risk algorithm deployment and to enable predictive and prescriptive autonomy.
- DRL shows promising tracking performance vs. NMPC in field trials, but interpretability and safety guarantees remain challenges.
- System identification with minimal sensors helps bootstrap models for control when instrumentation is limited.
- Classical guidance/observer designs continue to provide strong guarantees in currents and underactuation.

## Suggested Next Steps
- Compare NMPC vs DRL on your vessel model with shared scenarios and metrics.
- Incorporate COLREGs-compliant APFs with disturbance observers.
- Build a DT pipeline (AIS/LiDAR ingestion) to evaluate what-if cases before sea trials.
"}]}

我可以联网帮你查最新数据，不过刚才直接打开部分权威页面（搜索引擎结果、浙江大学本科招生网、阳光高考等）时遇到反爬或连接限制，没能直接获取到具体分数与位次。

为避免误差，先确认两点：
1) 你想查的是本科高考录取，还是研究生（推免/统考）？
2) 若是本科，请提供：省份、选科要求（物理等）、想看的口径（投档线/位次/最高-最低-平均分/招生计划数）。我就能定向抓取对应省考试院或浙大本科招生网的页面给你精确数据。

同时给你几条权威查询路径（你也可把页面链接发我，我来代查）：
- 浙江大学本科招生网（各省投档线/分数线/计划）：bkzs.zju.edu.cn（有时需从首页导航“录取查询/各省分数线”进入）
- 各省教育考试院官网（“本科批投档线/录取统计”栏目）
- 阳光高考平台（高校分数线-浙江大学页）

背景提示（不代替具体数据）：2024年计算机类在各顶尖高校普遍竞争最激烈，浙大“信息类/计算机类”在多数省份的投档线与位次基本处在全省顶尖区间，常高于同校不少专业。具体到你所在省份和批次差异很大，建议用权威投档线和位次对照。

告诉我你的省份和想看的口径，我立即再试联网抓取并整理成清单发你。
